experiences.title: Senior Web Developer
experiences.summary: Was a member of many teams on many projects, creating many important parts of the site, as well as much of the infrastructure behind it.
bullet_points: Primary developer of the ever evolving, and improving, frontend assets management system, which has been through four or five major rewrites as requirements expanded and technologies improved.
Primary developer of the cart dialog, which has like-wise evolved.
Wrote many foundation/library modules used widely throughout the organization (and beyond).
Was instrumental in making Gilt responsive.
Developed two generations of the checkout process.
Proactively improved code quality and code quality tools.
Evangelized best practices for Javascript, CSS, and HTML.
Evangelized Gilt Tech at meetups and via blog posts.
Mentored junior engineers.

experiences.title: Web Developer
experiences.summary: Was part of a multidisciplinary team of web developers, systems engineers and designers working on several popular websites including Webfetti, iWon, and Zwinky Cuties.
bullet_points: Worked on a wide variety of projects, using various technologies. Most projects used JSTL on top of JSP. Client side code usually used Javascript and jQuery, or were Flash/Flex based.
Worked directly with designers to create designs that would work on all modern browsers.
Google Analytics (aka Urchin) used to track user flow through the site.
jQuery used for most dynamic content because of its conciseness and flexibility.
Developed an innovative Flash 10 copy to clipboard button, because of FP10 security issues.
Multi-tasked working on multiple new features, defect remission, and maintenance.
Proposed ways to improve projects, including new features, and refinements to existing ones.
Was proactive in making sites XHTML compliant, and Javascript bug-free.
Consistently completed projects under budget.

experiences.title: Developer
experiences.summary: Worked on a HTML/VBScript based Courts & Justice solution, specifically on the Case Management and Law Enforcement teams. Spent most of my time on small teams using an Agile/Scrum life cycle.
bullet_points: AJAX used to communicate between client and server-side components.

All client-side data was represented by XML, which was usually converted to HTML using XSL and XPath. All server-side data was stored in a SQL Server database; developers wrote their own Stored Procedures.

Data was usually preprocessed in a server-side COM+ component before being saved. All new components were written in C#, however, legacy components were written in VB6, and required knowledge of VB6 for maintenance purposes.
Visual Source Safe was originally used for source control, but was replaced by AccuRev.
Jira was used for tracking defects, while Rally was used for tracking projects.
